instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Hi ladies and gentlemen - its the macbook air week! Welcome to our show!


This one turns on but no image (thus no backlight) - it powers on, green/orange light ok, CPU gets hot.

<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 0V (no shorts to ground in the vicinity) and so is signal <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> (this comes from CPU). I measure L8550 VLDO and VDDIO to be ok at 5V and 3.3V respectively.

Have no spare LCD to try - I do but it belongs to another customer and I dare not damage it.


So since there is no image and I have no other LCD what could I do to go further? (Unless testing another LCD is generally risk-free).

Any way to test if LCD is detected to rule that out?


duke, I will waste some of your time after all :D 


george

threads.message: no chime, no mouse light.. I have the motherboard lying on the bench - the mouse should still light up right? IO board & flex connected of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: So it is brain dead. Was this a liquid spill? Voltage on L7310?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Happy New Year to you and everyone.

Brain dead means?

1.74V at L7310.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: All power is ok but it does not boot. What is the history?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
It was not LD - I didn't confirm that earlier - but I would have mentioned it - and the owner is a student (girl) who says it just stopped working. Using original magsafe.

should we look towards EFI or the CPU itself?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image/bklt - missing <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> to <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: This could really be anything. I would inspect the board closely for damage and then the first thing to try is the ROM. Backup the old! Besides that I don't think there is much you can do in these cases.
